content.text:
# Suggestion: **Last seen**

Wouldn't it be useful/informative if the profile page of a given ID were showing that ID's latest addition to their log?

Many actions ‚Äî e.g., block/unblock, subscribe, profile update ‚Äî are less visible in many clients, and custom actions may be entirely invisible to the casual user.

I feel it would be useful with a ‚ÄúLast seen [some time units] ago‚Äù on a user's profile page, as a rough indication of freshness of their feed.

What do you guys think?

----

/cc #ssb-dev
I like it!

content.text:
# Feedless: the non-addictive social network

Hello scuttle friends!

Thanks to scuttlebutt, I was able to build the social network idea I've had for years: take all the good original ideas from popular social networks (facebook, twitter, snapchat) but remove all the things that cause you to be addicted to them, such as news feed, and as you can guess from the name, Feedless has no feed of anything

Take a look: https://feedless.social/

I'm using SSB for everything in the backend, and the content is pretty much compatible to patchwork, so it is basically just another SSB client that you can use. I know decentralisation is core of SSB, but I built as a website for ease of use for non-techies (with both desktop and mobile web versions). If you don't want to use my server, not a problem, you can also download the electron app and use it just like patchwork. I also plan to build an iOS app soon (this one will be true decentralised like manyverse)

The code is on GitHub if you want to take a look: https://github.com/rogeriochaves/feedless

Please, give me all the feedback you can :D

![Captura de Tela 2020-04-29 aÃÄs 10.23.18.png](&GCQ5gpTt7JWKQMYNge/YGxdlBvPSn5frDbz4KawF1zY=.sha256)

content.text:
[@"Fred" in "Toulouse"](@9BbJwPDjcyIqrOUPNn0nJZBduWdIrpMk3Cjz5MP361s=.ed25519) the tech is the impressive HTML, CSS and the all-new JavaScript hahahah

Since I had only very simple needs after removing most interactiveness and push-based interactions from regular social networks I realized a simple website was all I need, also I wanted to avoid wasting any time configuring dev tooling or anything else that was not the product itself. Usually pet projects is where I go nuts with overengineering but this time was the other way around. For iOS app I also want to try to use plain Swift for the UI.

[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) also commented that I've done it in less then 30 days, and yeah, I'm happy myself with the speed I could develop this, and it's mostly because I'm following the Evolutionary approach I describe in [this blogpost](https://medium.com/@_rchaves_/designed-v-evolutionary-code-d52a54408c8f)

> I created an account online, but didn‚Äôt received my secret by email.

The email should work, I wonder if others are facing the same problem :/

> It as a limit on message size display (how much?), and they cannot be opened‚Ä¶ Am I right?

The message has a limit of 140 characters, and get split if has more then that, but yeah I still need to work on many improvements to split and limit better, display replies, maybe be able to open them separately, etc

> It is better to run web SSB interface on localhost or behind a ‚Äú.htpassword‚Äù protected zone.

I'll follow up with you on that!

content.text:
maybe I can release an alpha later tonight. I will have celebratory :icecream: if that works. The current working features are:

* custom URLs in the form of `ssb:<msg id>`.
* browse a thread.
* view public feed.
* view a profile. Includes avatar, description and last 10 messages for now.
* post new messages of type post. Including posting in specific channels and replying to some thread.
* Renderers for the following message types have been implemented:
  * post
  * vote
  * contact
  * channel
  * private (as in other peoples private msgs, we just say :padlock: private)

So it is quite basic but it kinda works.

Friends, just a sanity check here before I end up using some old modules. What are you folks using to post messages from your clients? I am considering using the core `sbot.publish()` with the object generated from [ssb-msg-schemas](https://github.com/ssbc/ssb-msg-schemas). Still, I saw that the last commit to that module was on 2017, so I wondered if people moved to something else.

#patchfox reached the point where navigation, threads, profiles, public, all kinda work so I think it is good time to add posting features.
#invocation anyone knows?

# LIST ALL CLIENTS

Hey friends,

Can we have a thread listing all known Scuttlebutt client applications (including incomplete ones)? We can try posting one client per reply with a brief description, maybe a shot.

# Patchfox
Patchfox is a SSB client packaged as a WebExtension for #Firefox.

* **Chanel:** #patchfox 
* **Status:** Incomplete (as of Feb of 2019)
* **Web:** https://github.com/soapdog/patchfox

![Screenshot - Patchfox](&LsTvLUXmlG55ZhaBB0khFmjSTOqk2Bc25Jm8UoTwQw8=.sha256)

content.text:
# Patchbay
Patchbay is a scuttlebutt client designed to be easy to modify and extend. It uses the same database as Patchwork and Patchfoo, so you can easily take it for a spin with your existing identity.

* **Chanel:** #patchbay (There are many other channels that start with `#patchbay` such as #patchbay-love #patchbay-dev as well)
* **Status:** Ready for usage, improving constantly!
* **Web:** https://github.com/ssbc/patchbay


![Screenshot - Patchbay](&rqug5Z3FPVV6hVh5b9loYEFf6sZ9KvQo/usGV300w6k=.sha256)
_Patchbay has an awesome tabbed interface_

content.text:
So friends, I was talking with [@kas](@RuNxm8SRujPcJx6GjtTQHp6hprAFv5voEkcvoAkB8Pk=.ed25519) in %1U5ivMEjNgJ9qpDWhwtsQxrp/fBdbnZSBVEZfWRxzes=.sha256 and had an idea.

Why don't we add a `about` message that marks a blob as _ephemera_? So, suppose I am posting some coffee photo, I could at that time, check something in my client like _mark this blobs as ephemera_. This way, clients would _know_ that these blobs are not important and thus safe for deleting in case they wanted to.

What people here think about this? I can see this being useful for #manyverse

A sub-suggestion:

On Usenet you can set an `Expires: $DATETIME` header as a suggestion to clients/servers that the article can be deleted after that time. This is useful for periodical postings like FAQs, nodelists, and such, so that old and obsolete material can be purged from the system.

So while the _ephemera_ flag is boolean, we could achieve greater granularity with an _expires_ field. The UI could show a radio box that sets a default _expires_ time, with an option to manually ring in a datetime before publishing. An unticked box means ‚Äòjust keep this forever‚Äô, like today.

content.text: i like the idea a lot [@SoapDog](@gaQw6z30GpfsW9k8V5ED4pHrg8zmrqku24zTSAINhRg=.ed25519) but I think it has to be accompanied by a really intuitive and _easy_ UI element that actually encourages folks to click it when appropriate. That's the hard part of this idea. You need to default to non-ephemeral because you don't want important things purged early, but that means you need people to take on extra work to mark an _unimportant_ thing as such. "meh, this doesn't really matter.... let's do _extra work_ for it" is something that's frequently hard to overcome in the UI.

authorProfile.name: masukomi
authorProfile.description: explorer, programmer, writer, esperantisto

content.text:
>  but imagine if you could make rules in the client software such as "mark blobs from me to channel (#)coffee as ephemera by default"...
> Also, since the expiry/ephemera message is a linked message, it can be added at a later moment, so you could provide a blob manager that allows you to select multiple items and mark them later, like Adobe Lightroom allows you to tag photos....
> What do you think about this? - [@SoapDog](@gaQw6z30GpfsW9k8V5ED4pHrg8zmrqku24zTSAINhRg=.ed25519)

I think it would function but very few people would take the time to set it up per channel.  Why bother? There's no benefit to them, just additional work. As for tagging later, same problem. I receive no benefit from the extra work. It's just extra work. 

I'm not sure there's a good solution to this. You need to make _no_ work (or a minimal one time effort) be the default and yet somehow manage to distinguish between "this is worth keeping" and "this is just throwaway" without need of constant effort. 

You might get close with an algorithmic solution, like anything that's received "enough"  replies is considered non-ephemeral, whereas if you post a picture and no-one says anything (or you only get "likes") maybe it's ok to purge that...

I think the solution here is something client side that doesn't require sending out new messages. Pubs still need to store everything in case someone wants it, but clients can just get more aggressive about getting rid of stuff. Yes, I realize this is completely unscalable for pubs, but I think it's the reality we're currently in. 

I do like your idea, but i don't currently see a way to do it that actually meshes with standard human behavior.

content.text:
[@masukomi](@LzTjF5eAVC6xprPMGeNzqEP/EEBIGpM6hDaaY10hrz8=.ed25519) just brainstorming here, but imagine if you could make rules in the client software such as "mark blobs from me to channel #coffee as ephemera by default", so that you could fine tune your own experience with rules that makes sense to you. I agree that creating a good and compelling UX for this is very hard if you're trying to serve everybody. Now, if you just create a toolkit and let users build their own UX, we can have very good UX as it will satisfy whoever built them. Also, since the _expiry/ephemera_ message is a linked message, it can be added at a later moment, so you could provide a blob manager that allows you to select multiple items and mark them later, like Adobe Lightroom allows you to tag photos.

What do you think about this?

content.text: [@Ram](@yo0bazpHRIdrHPQcbdSbxaRlprHBxUcrnNN5vmTDAaA=.ed25519) how does federation help a helpdesk system? Federation is more of a pain in the butt than centralization, and centralization makes it way easier to revise and update stuff. Helpdesk systems are typically used by a central group that's maintaining it for a product / service. The location of the people updating it is irrelevant, but the fact that it's just a limited set of people working together and NOT something open to the public means a centralized system is _way_ easier on... pretty much every metric. There are many cloud based systems that'll replicate your db and allow failover if your centralized server goes down. Hell most helpdesk systems can be generated as static html and no-one would know. You just need to hook in a decent search. So much easier to host, backup, failover, etc than a federated system with round robins and all that.

content.text:
# Markdown mentions

I've noticed that many (most?) SSB clients publish mentions as full Markdown links, but some seem to be publishing just `@name`. Does anyone know which clients are doing this? Patchwork and Patchbay publish full Markdown links like:

```
[@name](@GV2qQKe0Hzy1ArooeUqPlv2ZJOylWp/2k965SU0tZG4=)
```

Here are some examples of non-Markdown mentions:

- %9J3eq3q7zEOevm53vr14kYit+hlaBDDKuHa9ez3kfII=.sha256
- %gGeDKVMa2n7EUCfaD7EUHgftyL3v1iw0SIlvpguDYK4=.sha256
- %tssMC94yquE/sZ/TMtVabNY+4sKVmLg4GVPj2Jd+3Ds=.sha256
- %G5XnARfu2pxEZLURr/6WPkbo8CVzbt+QETPUR9+FdGQ=.sha256

**Is this happening only in #manyverse and #patchfoo, or are there other clients doing the same thing?** These mentions only seem to work on simple alphanumeric names when using ssb-markdown, so I'm wondering whether it would be possible to link the feed when publishing rather than trying to do lookups in the Markdown renderer.

cc: [@kas](@RuNxm8SRujPcJx6GjtTQHp6hprAFv5voEkcvoAkB8Pk=.ed25519) [@CustomDesigned](@iOyfRmje5LFAErH7M3faTLNMQUTXCnjECbLtniVJ478=.ed25519) [@cel](@f/6sQ6d2CMxRUhLpspgGIulDxDCwYD7DzFzPNr7u5AU=.ed25519) [@andrestaltz_phone](@+UMKhpbzXAII+2/7ZlsgkJwIsxdfeFi36Z5Rk1gCfY0=.ed25519)

Manyverse doesn't handle `@dominic` (it's rendered as it is), and `[@dominic](@.........)` is a link but it doesn't navigate anywhere when clicked. I'm planning to have Manyverse reflect the same behavior as Patchwork, but it won't use ssb-markdown, instead I'll make one mdast util for each specific markdown manipulation. See these other mdast utils that I made: https://gitlab.com/staltz/mdast-normalize-react-native/blob/0541bbf551831f3ae64dafc0741ff0912dcf3ea9/package.json#L20-24

Cultural background:
I'm multicultural (not multiethnical), because I was born in Brazil but lived in the USA during 4 of the key years of my childhood, and am now living in Finland for the last 9 years. I don't fully identify myself with any of those three countries/cultures, but they seem to balance each other in influencing my background. It is quite inaccurate to call me Brazilian, as well as it's inaccurate to call me Finnish. This used to be a matter of shame/discomfort for me in the past, nowadays I appreciate this fuzzy cultural alignment.

Communication style: 
Probably a blend of those cultures. I mean only what I say (I don't communicate by implying or suggesting), I speak directly which can be misunderstood as an intent to be rude, but honestly it's more about simplicity of thought and straightforward messages. I like to think about problems and challenges and uncomfortable truths, these actually motivate me to either solve them if they are solvable, or to study them and learn something philosophical if they are unsolvable. I try to be sensitive with this tendency though, because problems and challenges and uncomfortable truths can be demotivating to others. It's safe to assume I have a friendly tone while I'm direct, and if there's miscommunication/misunderstaning I'll try to apologize. 

Political background:
I'm left-leaning but not to a specific ideology, I just believe that a society worth living in is egalitarian (egalitarian upon people's worth, not upon their function in society), inclusive, non-competitive, fair, balanced, symbiotic (everyone and everything is vital to the whole). I don't have a black-and-white alignment, and can reasonably talk about the positive (isolated?) effects of capitalism, but in the end of the day I can't psychologically align myself with meritocracy, superiority, zero-sum competition, centralization/assimilation, hegemonies, accumulation of power, individualism, and the likes.

RPG alignment: Neutral Good

Business background:
In the past I have had a startup, nowadays I do consulting and training as a self-employed person. You could say I have the mind of product designer and CEO. This and other aspects of Manyverse has often led people to believe that Manyverse will at some point become a business. That's not going to happen, I'm personally fond of a donation-driven style of project development.

Blocking style:
I will block accounts that post content NSFW, accounts that intentionally disrespect others, and occassionally "random" accounts (or just unrelated to me) that I am not sure I want to host on my local SSB database.

content.text: PS: mdast is markdown AST used by [remark](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark), I really like the plugin architecture in remark and I think it would be a good fit for the SSB ecosystem.

Communication style: 
Probably a blend of those cultures. I mean only what I say (I don't communicate by implying or suggesting), I speak directly which can be misunderstood as an intent to be rude, but honestly it's more about simplicity of thought and straightforward messages. I like to think about problems and challenges and uncomfortable truths, these actually motivate me to either solve them if they are solvable, or to study them and learn something philosophical if they are unsolvable. I try to be sensitive with this tendency though, because problems and challenges and uncomfortable truths can be demotivating to others. It's safe to assume I have a friendly tone while I'm direct, and if there's miscommunication/misunderstaning I'll try to apologize. 

Political background:

I don't have a black-and-white alignment, and can reasonably talk about the positive (isolated?) effects of capitalism, but in the end of the day I can't psychologically align myself with meritocracy, superiority, zero-sum competition, centralization/assimilation, hegemonies, accumulation of power, individualism, and the likes.

content.text:
[ Forked from [%g3hPVP‚Ä¶](%g3hPVPDEO1Aj/uPl0+J2NlhFB2bbFLIHlty+YuqFZ3w=.sha256 "Replacing sigils links with URIs") ]

# Why base64?

> * Digests are encoded with a URL-safe base64 (replacing + with - and / with _)

**TL**;**DR**: Is there a reason we choose base64 instead of just using the same SHA256 hex digest that is used to store blobs on disk?

The only benefit I can see is saving 20 bytes. The downside is that the blob is represented by one string in the UI and by another on disk. And while it's easy to write a script that converts a base64 representation to an actual filename on disk so that one can access the file (inspection, deletion, statistics, ‚Ä¶) it is counter-intuitive (and counter-productive for the casual user).

**I suggest** we skip the whole base64 thing ‚Äì URL-safe or not ‚Äì and use the hex digest both in the UI and on disk.

If we're absolutely hell-bent on saving a few bytes, we could use base36 (`[0-9a-z]`) that weighs in at 50 bytes for a SHA256 hash.

## Comparison

```
hex    (64 bytes)
  fedcba9876543210fedcba9876543210fedcba9876543210fedcba9876543210
base36 (50 bytes)
  6coenzgadpereqfqiweqlg6w51buz1ju66rak7toep311d2780
base64 (44 bytes)
  _ty6mHZUMhD-3LqYdlQyEP7cuph2VDIQ_ty6mHZUMhA=
```

## Stray thoughts

A pro for both hex and base64 is that they are readily available in most, if not all, programming languages.

As for the hex digest, no further conversion is necessary once the SHA256 hash has been calculated, and the representation is both URL and filesystem safe. Also, the hex digest is case-insensitive.

Base64 has been in use on-disk in `~/.ssb/ebt/` for some time. Earlier versions included the padding character, `=`, the current implementation seems to use URL-safe base64 sans padding.

Some terminal emulators [on Linux] do not include base64's padding character by default when selecting a base64 hash by double-clicking it.

Base36 is short, neat and case-insensitive ‚Äì and sometimes funny words turn up in unsuspected places.

When I post a single 36 kB picture ([the median blob size](%48ulqS/byD4C4SGJWc9h3gd5/huTUwpqkDepbUfUiJA=.sha256 "I decided to do a breakdown of the file sizes of blobs in my ~/.ssb/blobs/sha256 directory")) I have already spent the 20-bytes-savings from more than 1,800 SHA256 hashes written as base64 instead of hex.

Base64 is ugly.

content.text:
Just came back from a walk on the beach :sunglasses: and I was thinking on how an ecosystem of SSB applications would function.

One of the first things we notice when running two `scuttlebot` instances at the same time is that they conflict with each other. Both in desktop and mobile apps, which I have noticed when testing my own boilerplate along side #mmmmm.

That seems like a problem at first, but it could also be a good thing. We could have a single application run `scuttlebot` and have other apps act as light clients. Such idea has been expressed before in the form of #ssb-shell, proposed by [@mix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) I believe.

That's what I've been thinking for the #open-app-ecosystem [application-hub](https://github.com/open-app/application-hub), both for desktop and mobile, and would like to know if that is really the path other people see SSB ecosystem of applications going to.

A technical problem I see with this solution though is, how are `flumedb` plugins to be installed without re-packaging the application?
[@jeswin-n53](@LgNKrZrNV6ZX+0fwW745oR/U6mVjNIia00MNeuJhYaQ=.ed25519) without knowing enough about it, I wonder if the Hurdle 1 issues are what holochain is trying to address.

content.text:
re [client poll](%A8H47IPGp2sxPYYFunKU+9mU52R7pvs8eKEsuFzaWXI=.sha256):

tl;dr patchfoo currently / maybe something patchcore based again in the future

cringe..! prepare for some whining (also because I had to write this three times since I lost the previous attempts in `<textarea>`s) please bear with me...

I feel fragmentation churn after going through a couple of installs of various clients.

my main client was patchfoo for quite some time. I jumped of patchbay@7 because it felt really slow compared to pb6, which I blamed on it's weird `var cache = {}` objects and couldn't get the depject model in my head or didn't try enough or didn't have the capacity to do so at the time or $reasonz.

I tried patchwork recently again at it's _much_ faster than the last time I tried. I guess because of the flumeview/reduce plugins it now uses(?)

Minbase worked okay in the browser but I don't want to load my main key in there and feel like I'm churning myself and others with multi-key identity splitting enough (can't wait for `sameAs`... :).

patchsix feels as fast as the good ol' days but still has that weird scrolling issue where I need to shrink the window until the bars appear so I can get more content. Rather wait for the minbase port.

I'm really happy with patchfoo because of how simple and fast it is. I want to see patchbay at that level again.

I also like the _old style_ approach of having a separate `sbot server` and running multiple clients against it, like git-ssb-web, patchfoo, etc. I like the multiple processes because it works around nodejs' single event loop and memory heap limit and I feel like I have more control over my system if one of the processes flies through the roof.

I know that patchbay@7 and patchwork bypass this issue by opening multiple electron windows but these embedded sbots then require different plugins which in some cases lead to problems when using them with other clients.

%patchfoo doesn't run with the embedded sbot of %patchbay for example:

```
/home/user/patchfoo/lib/app.js:725
    this.sbot.links2.read({
                     ^

TypeError: Cannot read property 'read' of undefined
    at App._getFollows (/home/user/patchfoo/lib/app.js:725:22)
    at App.run (/home/user/patchfoo/node_modules/asyncmemo/index.js:33:8)
    at App.getFollows (/home/user/patchfoo/node_modules/asyncmemo/index.js:26:9)
    at App.filterMsg (/home/user/patchfoo/lib/app.js:693:8)
    at Render.renderMsg (/home/user/patchfoo/lib/render.js:308:12)
    at /home/user/patchfoo/lib/render.js:320:12
    at /home/user/patchfoo/node_modules/pull-paramap/index.js:41:11
    at /home/user/patchfoo/node_modules/pull-paginate/index.js:6:32
    at /home/user/patchfoo/node_modules/pull-paramap/index.js:33:7
    at /home/user/patchfoo/node_modules/looper/index.js:11:9
```

Which smells like I should add `ssb-links` to pb's sbot but the last time I went there only resulted in more pain [*](%ICGxXmtRKX2RhQhgz2qlSodkuWfL+YdutBXfNKWQYOE=.sha256).

However to get patchbay to run against my vanilla standalone sbot using `npm run dev`, I had to replace `.use(require('./plugins/private'))` with `.use(require('ssb-private'))` in scuttlebots `bin.js` because of what looks like a naming conflict. At this point I honestly don't know what I'm doing anymore but I guess I removed my way to post private messages..?

Also: running multiple sbots at the same time leads to _really scary_ i/o lock errors which I hopefully never have to explain to anybody. I'm not sure how to advance here but I don't like where we are at and just hope we don't have to make copys of `.ssb` for each client at some point.

Thanks, Bob!

I honestly hoped for some feedback from the core crew, especially on the `ssb-links` problem which bit me [before](%ICGxXmtRKX2RhQhgz2qlSodkuWfL+YdutBXfNKWQYOE=.sha256) as well and went unanswered, too.

I guess it's just the volume of traffic these days that sweps away content.


cc [@dominic](@EMovhfIrFk4NihAKnRNhrfRaqIhBv1Wj8pTxJNgvCCY=.ed25519) [@mmckegg](@FbGoHeEcePDG3Evemrc+hm+S77cXKf8BRQgkYinJggg=.ed25519) [@mixxx](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) [@cel](@f/6sQ6d2CMxRUhLpspgGIulDxDCwYD7DzFzPNr7u5AU=.ed25519)

content.text:
## Friend-only posts and follower requests

e.g. "Protected Tweets."

This is another approach to avoid a singleton public space.

Imagine a client where you can make "friend-only" posts.  All are encrypted to the same key.  When someone follows you, the client asks you if you want to send them your friend-key (e.g. "approve a follower request").

This provides a middle space between "public" and "one-to-one" so that neighborhood conversations can happen.  It also reduces the chance your conversations will end up indexed by Google and prevents them from being seen by SSB-scraping spiders that follow everyone they can find.  It's not meant to provide high-grade crypto-secrecy.

This makes a subjective space which can be seen locally with a small horizon but not mapped from the top down.

Unlike current private conversations: you can add and remove friends.  Newly added people can see old posts.  Neighborhoods form organically and subjectively instead of happening in prescribed groups that look the same to everyone.  It's a semi public space, not a private club.

When you remove a friend you would make a new friend-key and send it to everyone who you previously approved so they could keep reading.  ...And when you add a friend you would send them all your prior friend-keys as well as the current one so they could read your old posts.

You could even have multiple friend-keys for different social contexts or topics (coworkers, family, friends) though for simplicity I would suggest adding that later.

#ssb

In other words, I'd like SSB to be a [less legible](https://www.ribbonfarm.com/2010/07/26/a-big-little-idea-called-legibility/) space, a concept I learned about from Ribbonfarm.

I'll write more about this soon.

> The more I examined these efforts at sedentarization, the more I came to see them as a state‚Äôs attempt to make a society legible, to arrange the population in ways that simplified the classic state functions of taxation, conscription, and prevention of rebellion.  Having begun to think in these terms, I began to see legibility as a central problem in statecraft. The pre-modern state was, in many crucial respects, particularly blind; it knew precious little about its subjects, their wealth, their landholdings and yields, their location, their very identity. It lacked anything like a detailed ‚Äúmap‚Äù of its terrain and its people.

content.text:
## What does privacy mean to you?

I used to think it was "Upholding the comfortable rules of polite society to avoid embarrassment."

Now I mentally replace it with "Preventing people who have power over me from learning things that will result in them hurting me or trying to control me."

People with lots of power / privilege / personal sovereignty don't need to be secretive in the same way that people do who are under pressure from hate groups, bosses, abusive partners, credit rating agencies, etc.  I guess "privacy" has become "opsec".

We want SSB to be a place where nobody has power over us.  And some of us are able to live lives like that.  But it's hard to keep the power structures of the real world out of SSB when posts are Googleable, so I want to put a lot of attention on privacy-related sharp edges in SSB / clients and reframe the conversation into one about safety.

I'm not familiar with any of the client codebases yet but I'm going to study Patchwork and try to work on some pull requests.  Anyone want to form a safety taskforce with me?

#privacy #safety #ssb

Often, I want privacy just so that I can just communicate directly with one person and don't have to think about how everyone else will interpret it, and what opinions they'll want to "contribute". But privacy is a spectrum, there are many layers and reasons for privacy.

content.text:
## Idea: Threaded chatroom SSB client

The same message threads keep getting bounced to the top of our feeds whenever someone comments, but it's not great to sort through the old parts to find the new parts.

We could borrow the design of [Twist](https://twistapp.com/) which is a Slack competitor that adjusts things for better async communication between people.  Kind of halfway between email, Github issues, and Slack.

On the left there would be a sidebar of conversation threads, similar to email subjects or a list of chat threads in a modern chat app.  Clicking one of those loads up a chatroom-style view in the right pane - except it's designed for paragraph-sized messages, not one-liners.  That chatroom view shows you one post and all its comments.

New content in a thread makes it bold and bumps it to the top of the thread list on the left.  When you click into a thread, the right pane auto-scrolls to the new stuff.

I think it would feel a bit more organized to see a list of threads in one place instead of wandering around the maze of posts.  You could star or pin threads to keep them at the top of the list, etc.

## Threaded client update

![threaded_screenshot2.png](&dz0vJIe4FWGWyr7p8X9E+dwnI1y1WE1ds1PrU4B+RTU=.sha256)

This will look something like Facebook Messenger when it's done.  New replies to a thread will bump it to the top of the list on the left.

Lots still to do:
* thread messages should be more compact, like a chatroom
* add a box for writing comments
* show user names and icons
* show number of new posts next to a thread name like Slack does

Comments / feedback?

http://scuttlebot.io/ has improved a lot since I last looked and now has lots of documentation for the scuttlebot npm package.  Thanks whoever updated that!  Docs are worth their weight in gold.

It's incredibly satisfying to so easily build a new UI on top of a social network like this.  I love open source.  <3

content.text:
> Do people usually post these links with "git.scuttlebot.io" in front of them, or only starting with the hash part?

Either the git.scuttlebot.io link, or a localhost:7717 link, or the message id (the part after `ssb://` in the git URL), is okay. My preference is for the message id. Just not the URL part after the hostname (%25...%3D.sha256), because that is URL-encoded and thus not clickable in most ssb clients.

> How do I get this hosted viewer to absorb my changes?

Gossip with a peer, and then the pub hosting git.scuttlebot.io ( @5XaVcAJ5DklwuuIkjGz4lwm2rOnMHHovhNg7BFFnyJ8=.ed25519 ) should replicate your changes eventually.

> I also don't understand why the hosted web-views like git.scuttlebot.io sometimes hang forever when loading a page.

The software running it is inefficient. I set up git.scuttlebot.io to cache responses from git-ssb-web, which is supposed to make it load faster, but uncached requests are fully buffered before serving, which makes them slower. If you can, I recommend using a local git-ssb-web or other ssb client instead.
